conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the p-V diagram of an ideal gas to compare the internal energy at states a and c.
The p-V diagram shows the relationship between pressure and volume for different states of the gas.
Identify the states a and c on the p-V diagram. State a is at the bottom of the curve, and state c is at the top of the curve.
Understand the meaning of the p-V diagram. The p-V diagram shows the relationship between the pressure and volume of an ideal gas.
The internal energy of an ideal gas is related to its volume and temperature.
In an adiabatic process, the internal energy remains constant, while in an isochoric process, the internal energy changes.

premise: Since the diagram is for an ideal gas, the internal energy at state a and state c will be the same because they are both at the same temperature.
conclusion: Therefore, the internal energy at state a is equal to the internal energy at state c.

premise: Since the internal energy is constant in an adiabatic process, the internal energy at state c is higher than at state a because the gas expands from state a to state c.
conclusion: The internal energy at state c is greater than the internal energy at state a.
